stories.headline: Should California secede from the U.S.? One fictional family takes up the debate
stories.summary: The Mahoneys are having a family reunion on their sprawling Central Coast fruit ranch, and the story explores the debate around California independence through a collaboration with author Dave Eggers. The story examines the tensions and challenges of California potentially seceding from the U.S. through a narrative that interrogates the state’s political and social condition.

stories.headline: SFUSD kids fill up more seats at Lowell
stories.summary: Fewer private school students are enrolling at San Francisco's Lowell High School, with district students taking most of the available spots in the freshman class. This marks a notable shift from previous years when many students came from non-district middle schools. The district admitted 58% of private and non-district applicants this year, up from 74% in 2019. For the first time, all applicants were required to take the same admission test.

stories.headline: GOP may cap U.S. write-off for local taxes
stories.summary: Republicans are poised to permanently cap how much of the taxes paid to state and local governments can be deducted on federal taxes, impacting Californians significantly. The cap would limit deductions to $10,000 annually starting in 2025, down from higher previous limits, potentially increasing tax liabilities for many. This follows legislative changes including the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and a 2025 House Republican tax bill proposal. The SALT cap could raise $195.6 billion in revenue.

stories.headline: String of psychiatric crises linked to ‘Zizians’
stories.summary: The article links a series of psychiatric crises to a Bay Area blogger named 'Ziz,' who was connected to several violent deaths. Ziz, whose legal name is Jack LaSota, was a young transgender woman immersed in rationalist and Berkeley-centered movements. The story explores how her ideology and interactions, particularly online, may have influenced disturbing behaviors and mental health issues among followers or related individuals.

stories.headline: Bike lane driving gridlock, motorists say
stories.summary: Business and labor leaders near the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge toll plaza staged a rally to protest the bike lane, which they say causes traffic congestion and is wasted space. Despite the lack of bike use at peak times, officials say the lane remains for safety and policy reasons. Protest signs urged closing the bike lane, highlighting frustrations about traffic and housing issues in the area.

stories.headline: How $500 a month changed 3 lives
stories.summary: A two-year project studied whether a small monthly stipend could lift people out of poverty, sharing the experiences of a few participants and how the program impacted them.

stories.headline: They can't go home. They can't stay. What lies ahead for Ukrainian refugees in Delta Junction?
stories.summary: As the expiration of their humanitarian parole nears, many of the town’s more than 150 Ukrainians who fled war with Russia worry they'll be uprooted again. Sixteen-year-old Viktoriia and her family, who adapted to life in Delta Junction, face uncertainty as Russian troops invaded Ukraine in 2022, forcing them to leave behind everything. They receive support locally but face challenges as their parole nears its end, uncertain of their future in Alaska.

stories.headline: Republicans forge their tax bill in Trump's image
stories.summary: Republicans unveiled sweeping tax legislation days before President Biden's State of the Union address. The bill reflects many campaign promises of former President Donald Trump, including tax breaks on auto loans and new limits on IRS audits for American-made cars. The legislation aims to extend temporary tax promises, offering benefits to many workers and creating a new tax break. The Trump-inspired contours of the bill signal strong party influence on fiscal policy for the upcoming term.

stories.headline: Ravn Alaska plans to end scheduled service to more rural communities
stories.summary: Ravn Alaska announced it will terminate service to Valdez, St. Paul, and two other last rural communities it serves. The airline is giving notice to the U.S. Department of Transportation to end its service due to financial strain. This follows previous cutbacks and suspensions affecting other rural Alaska communities. The move impacts passengers relying on Ravn Alaska for connectivity to these regions.

stories.headline: Severe weather kills at least 27, with 18 dead in Kentucky
stories.summary: Deadly storms sweeping across multiple U.S. states have resulted in at least 27 fatalities, including 18 in Kentucky. The severe weather has caused devastating damage to homes, vehicles, and infrastructure, forcing closures of roads and delaying reopening efforts. The death toll continues to rise as rescue operations persist in affected areas.

stories.headline: Expansion has made big impact
stories.summary: An analysis of the Medicaid expansion highlights its significant positive impact on healthcare access and outcomes. Since 2010, the expansion has saved over 27,000 lives by increasing coverage, though some adults who gained coverage still face higher mortality than those without. The findings come amid political debates over cuts and reforms, underscoring the program's importance in supporting vulnerable populations.

stories.headline: Trump to push for end of war
stories.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump announced plans to hold talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss ending the war in Ukraine. Trump expressed hope that a ceasefire could be achieved soon, following a call with Putin regarding the conflict, signaling a potential shift towards diplomatic efforts to resolve the ongoing hostilities.

stories.headline: ‘A partner at the table’
stories.summary: Hamilton County leaders are urging Chattanooga to contribute a larger portion of its local option sales tax to the school system, arguing for more regional cooperation in education funding. The city counters that it already pays its fair share and that county governments allocate a larger share of property tax to education, fueling an ongoing debate about school funding equity and responsibilities.

stories.headline: Wilkeson, cut off from Mount Rainier, faces a fresh existential crisis
stories.summary: Wilkeson, historically a coal mining town, is facing a renewed existential crisis after being cut off from Mount Rainier National Park due to a bridge closure. Once thriving with coal production and a railroad connection, the town has adapted to outdoor tourism. The recent disconnection from a popular route complicates its future, creating new challenges for businesses and residents.

stories.headline: Joe Kent pressed analyst to redo intelligence on Venezuelan gang
stories.summary: Top adviser Joe Kent pressured an intelligence analyst to redo an assessment on the relationship between Venezuela's government and a gang after incomplete findings emerged. The situation relates to President Donald Trump's war crimes trial and investigations into U.S. intelligence matters, including involvement of other political officials.

stories.headline: Pioneer Square shooting leaves 3 people dead, another injured
stories.summary: A shooting in the Pioneer Square neighborhood early Saturday resulted in three deaths and one critical injury. Police found four adults with gunshot wounds at the scene. One man died at a medical center while others were at the crime scene. Police have increased patrolling in the area but no arrests have yet been made.

stories.headline: STUCK IN THE PAST
stories.summary: Amid a $94 million deficit, Seattle Public Schools is leasing land across the city at old 1980s-style rates, preserving some long-term ground leases. Despite enrollment drops and school closures, these leases generate revenues for the district, though at rates that don't reflect current market values. This approach helps offset some financial challenges but results in missing out on potential higher income from market-rate rents.

stories.headline: 'I THINK IT'S HERE'
stories.summary: An uprooted Afghan family has settled in Chicago after being rescued ahead of the suspension of a refugee program, highlighting immigration and resettlement challenges and the city's role as a refuge for displaced people.

stories.headline: Tribes fighting to remove pipeline
stories.summary: Indigenous tribes in the Great Lakes region, concerned about the environmental and cultural impact, have been fighting for over a decade to remove the Line 5 pipeline. Owned by Enbridge, the pipeline carries over 20 million gallons of crude oil and natural gas liquids daily, posing risks to the water quality of the Great Lakes. Activists highlight the danger of potential spills, although regulators currently require reporting only significant spills.

stories.headline: Rep. Jackson rents office from business partner
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Jonathan Jackson is renting a congressional district office on the South Side from Elzie Higginbottom, a close friend and business partner, at more than twice the rate paid by the previous tenant. The arrangement, involving substantial taxpayer dollars, raises questions about ethics and financial transparency as the partnership also owns local stores that benefit from federal programs.

stories.headline: 'I WANT TO BE THERE FOR HIM'
stories.summary: After Chicago native Pope Leo XIV made history as the first American elected pontiff, Rev. Homero Sánchez sent a congratulatory text expressing hope and support. Sánchez is elated to attend Pope Leo XIV's inaugural Mass in St. Peter's Square and shared that many Chicago-area Catholics are undertaking a 4,000-mile pilgrimage to witness the inauguration and celebrate other papal events.

stories.headline: Severe storms kill dozens in 3 states
stories.summary: Severe storms have caused significant damage across three states, resulting in dozens of deaths. Kentucky has been especially hard hit, suffering both a tornado and heavy rain-associated damage, highlighting the ongoing impact of extreme weather events.

stories.headline: Sox misplays help Cubs at Wrigley
stories.summary: The Chicago White Sox's self-destructive mistakes contributed to a win by the Cubs at Wrigley Field, with the final score being 7-3.

stories.headline: Are you a savvy seller?
stories.summary: Real estate professionals suggest that while agents may not always be necessary, their skills can greatly benefit homeowners lacking experience in selling homes, improving the chances and efficiency of sales.

stories.headline: Not a lost art
stories.summary: Artists in Chicago continue to keep the tradition of hand-painting signs alive, preserving this unique form of art and craftsmanship despite modern alternatives.

stories.headline: Pharmacy has history of violations
stories.summary: Empower Pharmacy, a Houston-based compounder competing against 'Big Pharma', faces legal challenges after reportedly suing a competitor. The pharmacy, which supplies millions of patients with personalized medicines, was previously scrutinized for its practices. The case portrays the ongoing tensions between independent compounders and large pharmaceutical companies.

stories.headline: Bills target offenders in youth prisons, limit advocates' access
stories.summary: Following a revealing Department of Justice report on sexual and physical abuse in Texas juvenile prisons, the state Senate approved bills that impose harsher consequences on juvenile offenders and restrict access for watchdog groups. Critics warn that proposed legislation could make it difficult for advocates to monitor conditions, potentially worsening the situation for vulnerable youth.

stories.headline: Probe shows agency's role in Lotto win
stories.summary: An internal inquiry into the Texas Lottery Commission reveals that professional gamblers were allowed to skirt state rules when purchasing numbers for a Lotto Texas draw to guarantee winning the $95 million jackpot. The confidential report completed this year reveals the agency's incursion in the scheme and the resultant negative publicity, which forced lawmakers to intervene.

stories.headline: GETTING PRICED OUT
stories.summary: Home values have risen sharply in many of Houston's working-class neighborhoods in the last decade, causing a threat to displace low-income communities. While the most expensive parts of town see rising prices slowest, the western half of the Inner Loop and surrounding areas have experienced a spike in home prices by 365% in the past decade. The shift threatens to disrupt long-established communities that may not afford the increased costs.

stories.headline: MORE PROBLEMS at KY juvenile justice centers
stories.summary: A Herald-Leader investigation found serious problems at the 30-bed Mayfield Youth Development Center in Graves County, including sexual trysts among employees and organized fights among detainees.

stories.headline: In many Pa. cities' primaries, the GOP is MIA
stories.summary: In the 2025 primaries across Pennsylvania, despite Republican gains in 2024, the GOP is notably absent in many large and midsize cities in the Philly area. This absence of candidates points to a lack of Republican presence in mayoral races of Democratic strongholds such as Allentown, Bethlehem, Lancaster, and Harrisburg, influencing upcoming elections.

stories.headline: An honor student's strength suffused with loss
stories.summary: George Lane, an 18-year-old honor student, has persevered through personal tragedy, including the losses of his two brothers, to achieve a full-ride scholarship. His accomplishments represent a foundation of talent and hard work, underscored by the motivation he draws from his family losses and community support.

stories.headline: After a patient is blamed, replay shifts the narrative
stories.summary: Jefferson Abington Hospital was cited for a guard's excessive use of force after a security video showed a woman being forcibly restrained during a mental health crisis. The hospital says protocol was followed, but the new footage raises questions about the incident and the guard's actions, spurring an investigation and public concern.

stories.headline: CPS' Skipping Surge
stories.summary: A quarter of Chicago high schoolers missed more than a month of school last year, yet graduation rates inched up over the last 5 years with CPS giving students many chances to get back on track. This is part one of a 2-part report by Sarah Karp and Mila Koumpilova.

stories.headline: Why is the CSO the only U.S. orchestra at the Coachella of the classical world?
stories.summary: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra (CSO) is the only U.S. orchestra performing at the Coachella of the classical music world, highlighting its unique position and acclaim in the classical music scene.

stories.headline: Illinois is last state unlawfully stripping homeowners’ wealth in tax foreclosures
stories.summary: Illinois has been identified as the last state unlawfully stripping homeowners of their wealth through unjust tax foreclosure practices, raising concerns about property rights and fairness in tax law enforcement in the state.

stories.headline: Hospital sounds financial alarm
stories.summary: North Memorial Health warns it might be forced to cut services or even close due to financial pressures exacerbated by reduced federal Medicaid funding and emergency care challenges. Spencer Kallestad's case highlights risks to trauma care at North Memorial's Robbinsdale hospital, underscoring the healthcare system's alarm over sustaining critical services amid policy uncertainties.

stories.headline: For state’s pensions, risk pays
stories.summary: Minnesota’s pension funds report strong returns despite economic uncertainty by embracing private equity investments and diversified holdings. The Minnesota State Board of Investment, responsible for managing three pension funds, cites higher risks yielding higher long-term returns, with leaders like Michael Markov emphasizing the importance of risk management in the evolving pension landscape.

stories.headline: CITY FINDS IT’S HARD TO STAY SMALL
stories.summary: Nowthen, a town in northern Anoka County, struggles with suburban growth and increasing density, facing a 'teeter-totter' of balancing taxes and services. Long fighting off density through incorporation and development controls, Nowthen now confronts rising community costs and growing pains with a new city administrator and expanded services, questioning how to sustain itself without losing its rural character.

stories.headline: Take to the water, right in the city
stories.summary: The Twin Cities metro area offers new ways to enjoy water activities, including canoeing and kayaking, suitable for beginners and pros alike. The local paddling spots provide options for lazy floats, vigorous day trips, scenic skyline views, and urban wildlife experiences, inviting adventurers to explore these accessible water routes within the city.

stories.headline: To dismay of the left, Walz leans to center
stories.summary: Governor Tim Walz shifts his political stance toward the center by signing a budget deal cutting spending and scaling back health coverage for undocumented immigrants. This move, driven by fiscal and political necessity amid a multi-billion-dollar deficit, faces strong opposition from progressive Democrats but reflects Walz’s new political reality and willingness to make unpopular decisions for moderation.

stories.headline: Deadly Path of Tornadoes
stories.summary: Extreme tornado storms devastated areas in Kentucky and Missouri, leaving widespread destruction and loss. The article documents the damage and human impact from these catastrophic storms.

stories.headline: Corner Where ‘I Can’t Breathe’ Ignited a Movement Confronts Its Own Struggle
stories.summary: The intersection of 38th Street East and Chicago Avenue in Minneapolis, where George Floyd was killed five years ago, remains a powerful symbol of protest and hope but also faces challenges with crime and community grief, reflecting ongoing struggles in the fight for racial justice.

stories.headline: The Iron Miners Lost Their Jobs But Kept Their Belief in Tariffs
stories.summary: Iron miners from Hibbing, Minnesota, faced layoffs but maintained their hope and belief in protective tariffs to safeguard their industry. The hardships highlighted the tensions between global economic forces and local livelihoods in the steel manufacturing sector.

stories.headline: Professors Face Student Rancor Over Use of A.I.
stories.summary: Instructors at Northeastern University are encountering pushback from students regarding the use of AI tools like ChatGPT in academic settings, prompting discussions about ethical usage, leadership challenges, and how AI influences education practices.

stories.headline: ANALYST WAS TOLD TO REDO FINDINGS ON VENEZUELANS
stories.summary: A top adviser to the director of national intelligence ordered an analyst to redo an assessment on Venezuelan government and gang ties after intelligence findings undercut the White House’s justification for deporting migrants. This order raises questions about political pressure influencing intelligence assessments.

stories.headline: G.O.P. Revolt Reflects Split On Spending
stories.summary: A faction of hard-right House Republicans, tax and spending cut proponents, opposed a bipartisan group’s package as the proposed bill was seen as too compromising, reflecting an ongoing split within the GOP on budget priorities and a struggle against broader social spending.

stories.headline: The Quiet Journey From Father Bob to Pope Leo
stories.summary: Father Robert Prevost, once a humble priest facing dangers in Peru, is on a journey towards becoming Pope Leo. His story highlights his commitment and transformation amidst political and religious turmoil and the challenges he faced from his early years to his current standing in the Catholic Church.

stories.headline: Religion is part of Boise State football. Is there coercion?
stories.summary: Boise State head coach Spencer Danielson and players faced accusations of "religious coercion" within the football program after shuffling a group into a makeshift press room for a prayer session before a pivotal college football playoff game. Danielson emphasized the importance of faith in his life and its influence on his behavior, but the incident sparked debate over whether such expressions of faith in sports programs may impose pressure on players.

stories.headline: Judge: Kohberger defense will suggest other perpetrators
stories.summary: During a pretrial hearing for Bryan Kohberger, accused in the stabbing deaths of University of Idaho students, Judge Steven Hippler allowed the defense to argue the possibility of alternative perpetrators. The judge instructed the defense to provide evidence rather than mere allegations and set a hearing for June 18 to address related motions.

stories.headline: Rite Aid plans to sell remaining stores in Idaho
stories.summary: Rite Aid announced it will sell its remaining three stores in Idaho, located in Boise and Caldwell, as it exits the state. These stores will continue operations during the transition. Rite Aid has also closed several stores in the Treasure Valley and has entered agreements to transfer pharmacy services for over 1,000 stores nationwide. The sales mark a continued departure of the company from the Idaho market.

stories.headline: Gag order investigation possible in Idaho student killings
stories.summary: Judge Steven Hippler issued orders to keep a gag order in place concerning the quadruple homicide case of four University of Idaho students. The gag order is part of a special prosecutor's investigation into possible violations related to non-dissemination of case information. The gag order was reinstated following revelations of previously unreleased details from an NBC "Dateline" episode and concerns that such violations could impact trial proceedings.

stories.headline: Can Trump legally accept $400M plane from Qatar?
stories.summary: There is debate over whether President Donald Trump can legally accept a $400 million Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet from Qatar's royal family. While some view the gesture as potentially unconstitutional and possibly corrupt, others discuss the implications under the U.S. Constitution's rules on gifts from foreign leaders. The issue involves legal, political, and ethical concerns around presidential gifts.

stories.headline: Foster care claims questioned
stories.summary: Executives of child welfare groups question the effectiveness of the Hope Florida program, claiming it duplicates existing services. Despite Hope Florida helping over 21,000 families, some stakeholders and former foster care agency leaders doubt the program's claims and its impact compared to established agencies.

stories.headline: An elegy for the Times building
stories.summary: The article reflects on the history of the Tampa Bay Times building, highlighting its significance in the community over a hundred years. It recounts the expansion in 1988 when a new structure was added, and the vibrant community it fostered among employees, journalists, and local leaders, acknowledging the building's eventual demise.

stories.headline: Hyde fired after rocky 2025 start
stories.summary: After a poor 15-28 start to the season, the Baltimore Orioles have fired manager Brandon Hyde. The decision comes following a series of losses and the team's fall to last place in the American League East. Third base coach Mansolino will serve as interim manager as the Orioles look to rebuild.

stories.headline: Israel launches new military operation in Gaza
stories.summary: Israel has launched a new military campaign aimed at pressuring Hamas to release hostages amid ongoing indirect talks involving a Qatari mediator. The operation reflects the escalating tensions and complex negotiations in the region.

stories.headline: First wave of Baltimore Catholic churches for sale
stories.summary: Five Catholic churches closed by the Archdiocese of Baltimore have been put up for sale. This marks the first wave of properties becoming available for sale since the Archdiocese began reorganization efforts last year.

stories.headline: Tornado touched down in Baltimore during storms
stories.summary: The National Weather Service confirmed that an EF-1 tornado with peak winds of up to 110 mph touched down in Baltimore's Federal Hill neighborhood. The tornado caused damage before moving east to Dundalk, highlighting the severity of recent storms.

stories.headline: Librarian Hayden loved a children’s book. Did it contribute to her firing?
stories.summary: Librarian Hayden, known for her love of a children's book about a girl with pigtails, was fired after controversy arose regarding the book's content. The incident highlights the complexities surrounding employment decisions tied to personal interests and cultural sensitivities, raising questions about the reasons behind Hayden's dismissal.

stories.headline: Walmart should ‘eat the tariffs’ and not raise prices on consumers, president says
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Walmart on social media for planning to raise prices due to tariffs. Trump urged the retail giant to absorb the costs rather than burden consumers, emphasizing his stance against tariff-related price increases amid tense trade relations between the U.S., China, and Russia.

stories.headline: FEMA aid an uphill battle
stories.summary: In Western Maryland, assessors estimate that flash flood damage could exceed $10 million. After catastrophic flooding, residents and local leaders are facing challenges in securing adequate federal aid from FEMA. The combination of state and federal funding is still not enough to cover widespread losses and infrastructure damage, complicating recovery efforts.

stories.headline: Moore, others gather on eve of Pimlico rebuild
stories.summary: Maryland politicians, including Moore, celebrated efforts to secure funding and support for the $500 million Pimlico Race Course redevelopment. The state has made historic investments to ensure a prosperous future for Pimlico and the surrounding neighborhoods, with hopes to revitalize the area and maintain its status as a premier horse racing venue.

stories.headline: Journalism wins
stories.summary: Journalism, led by Umberto Rispoli, won the 150th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course. Despite a challenging race with close competition, Journalism surged from behind to claim victory in the prestigious horse racing event, adding to the excitement of the annual Preakness Stakes.

stories.headline: Ready for the 'next chapter'
stories.summary: Graduating seniors at St. Michael's High School are preparing for their futures amid changes in the college and career landscape. Students like Liyah Cifuentes and Vanity Quintana reflect on their emotions and uncertainties entering college or the workforce, shaped by recent societal and educational shifts.

stories.headline: Supporters worry Plaza monument is beyond repair
stories.summary: Shattered pieces of the Soldiers’ Monument, toppled by protests on Indigenous Peoples Day in 2020, have been stored at Santa Fe Regional Airport. The monument has stirred controversy regarding whether it should be rebuilt due to extensive damage. A historic preservation group is legally challenging the city over plans, while a gag order limits discussions. Photos of the damaged obelisk are being made public for the first time as court battles continue.

stories.headline: ‘May your song always be sung’
stories.summary: Bob Dylan comes to Northern California, again reaching across generations with his music and influence. The story highlights Dylan's enduring impact on multiple generations and his continued relevance in the music world.

stories.headline: LOCAL: Coyote hunting limit proposal on hold after rancher protests.
stories.summary: A local proposal to limit coyote hunting has been put on hold following protests from ranchers who oppose the restrictions, showcasing the ongoing debates between wildlife management and agricultural interests in the community.

stories.headline: What do you want when you take a cruise? See how private resorts are changing travel.
stories.summary: An exploration of how private resorts are transforming the cruise travel experience, offering travelers new options and personalized services that cater to evolving expectations in the travel industry.

stories.headline: Amid fragile ceasefire, Kashmir contends with lasting devastation
stories.summary: Kashmir suffers from the aftermath of decades of violence and recent ceasefire tensions, with civilians grieving over high casualties in cross-border conflicts between India and Pakistan, highlighting the region's ongoing instability and human costs.

stories.headline: Crypto investors seek seat at president's table – and his ear
stories.summary: Cryptocurrency investors are increasingly seeking influence with President Donald Trump by attending exclusive events, hoping to shape policy and capitalize on Trump's views despite public controversies surrounding crypto and the president's practices.

stories.headline: Journalists flee El Salvador's crackdown on dissent
stories.summary: Facing arrest from President Bukele's government, top investigative journalists at El Faro have fled El Salvador amidst fears of authoritarian moves and tightening controls, highlighting severe threats to press freedom and democratic norms in the country.

stories.headline: DOGE uncoils a brain drain
stories.summary: The National Institutes of Health and other government bodies are facing a talent exodus with key leaders and staff in infectious disease research, health policy, and human genome research retiring early or leaving, causing concerns about long-term impact on federal health expertise and systems.

stories.headline: Catholics hope Leo is boon for the faith
stories.summary: In just 10 days, Pope Leo XIV, the first American pontiff, has brought new energy and traction to the Catholic Church amidst a divided faith, gaining momentum with a global presence and hopes of future growth not seen in decades.

stories.headline: Facing eviction
stories.summary: A family faces eviction after the landlord accused the mother of a crime, which cost them their home. The story explores the implications and details behind the crime-free lease addendum that played a role in this situation.

stories.headline: Reflecting our history
stories.summary: The new Indiana State Archives building is set to preserve the past and provide genealogists and researchers with resources to explore family heritage, offering enhanced support for those interested in their ancestry.

stories.headline: Dams failed in 2020. People are still rebuilding homes, lives.
stories.summary: Five years after the Mid-Michigan flood caused by the failure of several dams, residents like Julie Vezina are still working to rebuild their homes and lives. The flooding severely damaged Sanford Lake and surrounding areas, leaving many without electricity, plumbing, and comfortable living conditions. Efforts to restore the community continue as residents adjust to new realities and work to reclaim their properties.

stories.headline: ‘Still fighting to get justice,’ family says
stories.summary: The family of Patrick Lyoya, who was fatally shot by a Grand Rapids police officer three years ago, continues to seek justice. Patrick Lyoya's father expressed ongoing frustration that the police officer involved remains at home and his son remains buried without justice. The family struggles with heartache as they await accountability for the officer. Kent County officials and the family are actively engaged in the pursuit of justice.

stories.headline: Sticking around
stories.summary: Exposed to Portland's allure, more Maine college graduates are opting to stay. Census data indicate Portland's reputation as a desirable place to live has grown among recent grads and college-educated workers. Friends who attended Maine colleges agree Portland offers attractions like affordable dining and access to outdoor activities, influencing their decision to remain in the city after graduation.

stories.headline: Numbers indicate wide geographic disparity in the use of yellow flag law across the state
stories.summary: Maine's extreme risk protection order, known as the yellow flag law, is used very unevenly across counties. Some police departments rarely use the law despite its intent to seize guns from threatening individuals. The Kennebec County agency leads with 12 temporary confiscations in the past year, while many other departments have none. Officials attribute this to differences in enforcement procedures and awareness. The disparity reflects varied law enforcement approaches to preventing gun violence statewide.

stories.headline: Providers fear cuts will worsen access crisis in Maine
stories.summary: Providers in Maine are concerned that proposed spending cuts to Medicaid by congressional Republicans will deepen the access crisis. The budget proposal could cause an estimated 34,000 Maine residents to lose Medicaid coverage, affecting healthcare providers and patients. Despite support from President Trump, some Senate Republicans oppose cuts exceeding about $625 billion over 10 years. Bipartisan resistance has surfaced regarding work requirements for able-bodied adults, with the overall bill's impact on services remaining uncertain.

stories.headline: Abortion will go back on Missouri ballot in Republican effort to reinstate ban
stories.summary: Missouri voters will decide whether to reinstate an abortion ban next year through a landmark statewide vote. The Republican-controlled Senate approved a proposed constitutional amendment to overturn the previous abortion rights amendment, potentially reversing nearly 52% of voters who had approved abortion access. This move has sparked significant debate among supporters and opponents of abortion rights in Missouri.

stories.headline: CHILD CARE CRISIS
stories.summary: Johnson County is facing a significant shortage of day care centers, impacting families and costing one mom her savings. This highlights the broader issue of insufficient child care resources in the region.

stories.headline: A BARN BURNER IN NEW HAMPSHIRE BETWEEN CHURCH AND STATE
stories.summary: The Justice Department is supporting a religious group, Grace New England church, in a zoning dispute with the town of Weare, New Hampshire. The Kaloogian family established a church in a renovated barn, which has sparked conflicts over land-use approvals. The case raises issues about religious freedoms under laws such as the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), with local authorities attempting to enforce regulations on the church.

stories.headline: Courts hold the line on due process
stories.summary: The article discusses the federal courts' response to the Trump administration's aggressive deportation policies, emphasizing the courts' insistence on upholding due process. It highlights that immigrant courts are increasingly providing opportunities to challenge deportations despite the White House's push for swift removals, especially under new powers claimed for deporting Venezuelan immigrants from Texas.

stories.headline: Control issues at stake in fight over special needs student
stories.summary: Parent Carlee Hanslik-Buruliana alleges that her 7-year-old son was mistreated at Centerville Elementary, where he was placed in a padded room multiple times. Two police officers were sent to check on him. The parent says the school retaliated after she disputed the school's handling of her son, including incidents where the child was kicked and punched in the classroom. The case highlights concerns over the treatment and safety of special needs students in schools.

stories.headline: For Wu, fewer left turns this time out?
stories.summary: Michelle Wu, who was elected mayor in 2021, appears to be moving closer to the political center, having slowed her progressive initiatives like the Green New Deal and a free T. She recently criticized the Police Department budget and has rejected campaign contributions from police officers and unions. Wu's campaign seems less progressive now, with endorsements from major police unions and the district attorney, signaling a shift in political strategy.

stories.headline: Severe Weather Kills at Least 27 in Midwest and South
stories.summary: A powerful storm system swept through parts of the U.S. Midwest and South, causing at least 27 deaths, including 18 in Kentucky. The severe weather damaged homes, left many homeless, and led to widespread road closures. Officials warn that more deaths could occur due to ongoing hazardous conditions in affected areas.

stories.headline: The Final Battle: Coal Miners Wage Long Legal Fights for Benefits
stories.summary: Coal miners suffering from black lung disease continue to fight long legal battles to obtain benefits to pay medical bills and sustain their lives. Highlighting personal struggles, the story follows Jimmy Phillips and others affected by the disease, underscoring the ongoing challenges miners face as they seek justice and support.

stories.headline: Divided Democrats Set to Head to the Polls
stories.summary: As mayoral primary nears, Pittsburgh faces historic challenges and threats, including a close race between Mayor Ed Gainey and County Controller Corey O'Connor. The election will center on key ballot questions, with legal and political battles shaping the contest amid accusations of outside influence and factional divides.

stories.headline: SURVIVING A SERIAL KILLER
stories.summary: The story recounts the experience of a woman who was assaulted at the age of 11 by a serial killer, sharing her personal journey of survival.

stories.headline: Immigration crackdown
stories.summary: An undocumented man played Jesus on Good Friday at a Jupiter church. Ten days later, he was deported, indicating a strict immigration enforcement.

stories.headline: Two members of Congress call for federal investigation into Hope Florida charity
stories.summary: Two Democratic members of Congress have called for a federal investigation into Hope Florida charity, following concerns over a $10 million Medicaid settlement used solely for health services authorized by law and for the benefit of Medicaid recipients served by the charity. U.S. Representatives Kathy Castor and Darren Soto are urging federal authorities to review the settlement scheme to determine if any laws or federal regulations were violated.

stories.headline: Florida’s mass-deportation and immigration-enforcement blueprint explained
stories.summary: Florida has engineered a 37-page blueprint aligning with President Donald Trump's immigration crackdown to address long-standing federal bottlenecks in the state. The plan focuses on identifying, apprehending, detaining, and deporting undocumented immigrants, aiming to ease federal pressures like those on Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Customs and Border Protection. Florida’s strategy positions the state as a key partner in the Trump administration’s mass-deportation efforts, with federal authorities working closely with state agencies.

stories.headline: 'I'm super honored': 30 impressive South Florida students shine at the 2025 Silver Knight Awards
stories.summary: The 2025 Silver Knight Awards honored 30 high school seniors from Miami-Dade and Monroe counties for outstanding service projects. Highlights include a student who created a Special Olympics soccer and football team, another who provides menstrual pads to homeless girls and schools in Jamaica, and a student who raised money to build clean water wells in Africa. The awards celebrate the impactful community contributions of these young leaders.

stories.headline: Holmes' path to success was clear
stories.summary: Brad Holmes stood in the tunnel of the First Horizon Coliseum, observing mothers and fathers waving life-size cutouts of their soon-to-be graduates. A retired economics professor at North Carolina A&T, Michael Simmons, has been documenting student experiences since before Holmes' time as a defensive tackle. Holmes pursued his doctorate and has documented his journey from athletics to academia, exemplifying dedication and success.

stories.headline: It was 25 years ago a Detroit music fest changed city history
stories.summary: The Detroit Electronic Music Festival (DEMF) started 25 years ago, marking a pivotal moment in Detroit's cultural history. Despite initial skepticism about the event's impact, the festival endured, overcoming financial and marketing challenges to become a major part of the city's music legacy. The inaugural DEMF was a landmark for techno and the homegrown genre in Detroit.

stories.headline: Automaking evolves from dashboards to keyboards
stories.summary: Detroit has long sought to establish a software development reputation influenced by Silicon Valley. Legacy automakers are competing with West Coast tech firms by recruiting software talent to aid in the transformation from vehicles as hardware to vehicles as software-enabled machines. Many GM executives attended Michigan universities, highlighting the evolving role of tech skills in the auto industry.

stories.headline: How to describe L.A.'s musical style?
stories.summary: The Hear Now festival explores the dynamic and diverse musical styles of Los Angeles, focusing on classical music influences from composers like Stravinsky, John Cage, and Virgil Thomson. The festival highlights the city's rich sonic juxtapositions and its reputation as a home for musical innovation, despite sometimes being underappreciated internationally.

stories.headline: L.A. residents ask: What's the plan?
stories.summary: Months after devastating fires, Los Angeles residents express mounting frustration at the city's unclear rebuilding and disaster recovery process. The Emergency Management Department chief highlighted challenges in securing funding and staff for recovery, while city officials face pressure to allocate more resources as neighborhoods struggle to rebuild homes and infrastructure.

stories.headline: 1 killed in blast outside Palm Springs clinic
stories.summary: A suspected bomb blast outside a fertility clinic in Palm Springs resulted in the death of one person and injured at least four others. Officials believe the explosion was an intentional act of violence targeting the facility that provides fertility and IVF services, including to LGBTQ+ families. Authorities continue investigating, with law enforcement agencies on scene and efforts ongoing to identify the deceased and the motive.

stories.headline: Woman's death inflames debate over problem bears
stories.summary: Patrice Miller, 71, who lived alone in a small mountain house, died after being attacked by black bears in California. Her death has sparked controversy over hunting rules as some rural areas seek more leeway to manage problem bears. An autopsy showed Miller was likely killed by an animal after breaking into her home, marking a grim first in California history for a fatal bear attack.

stories.headline: Trump's visit to the Middle East produced little for Palestinians
stories.summary: Saudi Arabia and President Trump's tour of the Middle East mainly focused on dealings with Gulf states, Syria, and Iran, but failed to address the ongoing crisis in Gaza. Despite a flurry of diplomatic activity and billion-dollar trade deals, Palestinians in Gaza continue to face severe hardships with little visible progress or resolution from the visit.

stories.headline: Players resolute in face of fear
stories.summary: The local Venezuelan baseball team is building community strength and bonds amid concerns of deportation. Team center fielder Carlos Flores expresses the challenges faced by immigrants, including political persecution and economic downturn in their home country. Despite fear and uncertainty, players remain dedicated to their sport and each other while seeking support from U.S. immigration enforcement agencies.

stories.headline: Lights, camera ... Texas?
stories.summary: TV show creator and Fort Worth native Taylor Sheridan is advocating for stronger film industry incentives in Texas to prevent productions from moving to other states such as New Mexico. Senate Bill 22 aims to establish a $500 million fund over 10 years to boost the Texas Moving Image Industry Incentive Program, making Texas a more attractive filming location. Supporters believe it will revitalize the industry and attract top talent back to Texas.

stories.headline: Tens of millions lost in home-buying ruse
stories.summary: A house-flipping franchise owner has been accused of bilking investors out of tens of millions in a deceptive home-buying scheme. The Texas retiree was led into an 'ugly houses' investment opportunity but the franchise's business model meant investors lost money through excessive fees and interest payments. The franchise, known for its 'We Buy Ugly Houses' ads, would own properties and lease them back to investors at a loss, negatively impacting their returns.
